ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Continued to develop writing skills and public speaking, as well as learned about the detective story genre. Probably my second fav class at Yale
We learned about the evolution and tropes of the detective genre!
Pretty good knowledge of the detective genre, where the genre has gone over the years, and some insight into the "low-brow" reputation of detective fiction.
Analytical writing and discussion

I gained so much from this class: an understanding of the detective genre, experience reading some really good books, an appreciation for Professor Grimstad's style of analysis and literary perception, and much enjoyment from our class discussions.

This course improved my general analytical skills as well as my ability to view texts in the context of their genre. Through tracing the development of Detective Fiction I was able to watch the progression of tropes, themes, and societal attitudes. This course also improved my writing skills and elevated the level of my seminar discussions.
I learned about the history of the detective genre. I was exposed to the first works of detective fiction (Poe's Dupin stories) and more modern works (e.g. Auster's City of Glass).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The syllabus was incredible and diverse. loved it
Fascinating readings, amazing teaching, and a reasonable workload.
Readings are always super fun, especially if you like detective fiction in any form.

I thought this course was very well designed and the pacing felt appropriate. My only complaint would be how quickly we had to move through each text (not that the reading was rushed, simply that discussion could have always gone further). That being said, I understand that as the course spans centuries it is important to include many texts and there is not unlimited time in the semester. The pacing and scope of the assignments was good and the lack of prompts allowed for papers to focus on areas of interest rather than conforming to a predetermined idea.
Great books and positive discussion!
The breadth of literature and media in this course was fascinating! I enjoyed the fact that we did not simply read novels, but rather explored all forms of detective stories.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course worked fairly seamlessly online. The discussions, albeit slightly moved stiff than they would be in person, felt conversational and as normal as any seminars I have been in.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutley. Such a fun course, the work didn't even feel like work. Learned more about how to read closely and catch important themes, while also learning about a very interesting genre.
Absolutely! This course is incredible. One of my favorite Yale courses.
Yes, it was so fun! Professor Grimstad picked some great materials to study and really knows how to maintain discussion.
Yes! It's pretty fun, the material is fun, and professor grimstad obviously loves the genre.
Yes - it was a lot of fun and a great way to learn a new skill

Absolutely. Professor Grimstad is fantastic, and he really puts his all into making his class an interesting, thought-provoking, and enjoyable time. Even for someone who isn't necessarily so into detective fiction, it is thought about in such a way as to discuss important themes and ideas that can be more general. If one does like the genre, it is all the more fun and novel. It is simple in its style: reading, thinking, and talking, with some papers along the way. It is not too much work, and it is worth doing the work because that is the only way to ensure you get the most meaningful experience.

I would highly recommend this course to any student. I think that the accessibility of the texts and the nature of "lowbrow" literature allows for all people to engage with the work and the richness of the materials provides ample room for deep analysis. The discussions in the class were substantial and enjoyable, and the content was fascinating. Also, because of its specificity, this course fills a niche that no others would. Unlike many other English courses that can have overlapping syllabi, Detective Fiction explores a fairly untapped area of literature in terms of study. The texts were engaging, exciting, and manageable and the discussions were substantial.

Yes, I would. I would especially recommend this course to those who love mystery novels and movies and want to get a better sense of the genre. The readings were interesting and the class discussions were engaging. This class was probably the most enjoyable one I took this semester.
Yes!! If you have any interest in detective fiction, this is a great course to take (especially with Paul Grimstad!) The discussions are so interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
We met twice weekly in a virtual seminar format.
